Dual-atom catalysts have received increasing attention in electrochemical ammonia synthesis in recent years due to their ability to break the scaling relationship limit. Experimental and theoretical evidences have demonstrated that FeMo bimetallic co-doped nitrogen-modified graphene (FeMo@NG) can serve as an efficient nitrogen reduction catalyst. However, the thermodynamic reaction mechanism remains a topic of debate. In this study, we employed density functional theory (DFT) calculations to examine the nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) on FeMo dual-atom catalysts and the effect of sulfur modification on the catalytic performance. Two types of FeMo dual-atom catalysts, including 4-N and 3-N coordinated structures, exhibited low NRR thermodynamic and kinetic barriers. The calculated overpotentials are -0.34 and -0.37 V (vs. SHE), while the activation energy barriers are only 0.87 and 0.97 eV, respectively. Nine different sulfur substitution ways were considered to form the FeMo-anchored nitrogen, sulfur-modified graphene (FeMo@NSG) catalysts. It was found that the formed FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2, in which the sulfur atom replaces the nitrogen atom simultaneously bonded to Fe and Mo atoms, can enhance the NRR performance dramatically. The FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2 catalyst exhibits a lower overpotential of -0.15 V (vs SHE) and faster kinetics with an energy barrier of 0.77 eV than other catalysts. The electronic structure analysis reveals that the modification of the S atom decreases the d-band center and weakens the adsorption ability of the active metal center, thereby resulting in a moderate oxidation state and higher reactivity. Therefore, this catalyst FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2 will possibly possess a significant advancement in the field of electrochemical ammonia synthesis. This work not only predicts a promising dual-atom electrocatalyst candidate for NRR but also contributes to the advancement of efficient NRR catalysts by regulating atomic coordination environments. Graphical abstract We investigated the NRR mechanisms, thermodynamics, and kinetics of FeMo dual-atom catalysts. The introduction of sulfur can further promote the NRR reactivity by regulating the oxidation states. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Density functional theory Electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction Dual-atom catalysts Bimetal doped N S-modification graphene Reaction thermodynamics and kinetics Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) plays a pivotal role in global industry and agriculture, and is increasingly recognized as an energy storage intermediate and clean energy carrier [1]. Currently, the industrial production of NH3 mainly relies on the conventional Haber-Bosch method, which operates under extremely rigorous conditions (∼500 °C and 150–300 atm) and results in significant greenhouse gas emissions [2,3] Accordingly, it is imminent to explore green and fusible ways for artificial nitrogen gas (N2) fixation. The electrochemical conversion of nitrogen reduction reaction (EcNRR) is acknowledged as a sustainable and environmentally friendly alternative approach to the Haber-Bosch method for NH3 production under ambient conditions [4]. Nevertheless, the electrochemical NRR still faces significant challenges, including high overpotentials and low selectivity [5]. Thus, the development and design of ideal electrocatalysts with enhanced activity, efficiency as well as selectivity are urgently desirable for EcNRR processes. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have attracted substantial attention among various catalysts due to their exceptionally high stability and 100 % atomic utilization in elctrocatalytic [6,7] and photocatalytic NRR [8]. Nevertheless, the intrinsic adsorption energy scaling relationship of SACs imposes fundamental limitations on the reaction thermodynamics and kinetics, particularly for intricate reactions encompassing multi-step procedures, such as CO2RR and NRR [9]. Recently, dual-atom catalysts, formed by incorporating a second metal atom, have garnered significant interest within the field of heterogeneous catalytic reactions [10–13]. These catalysts offer the potential to increase metal loading and enhance reaction efficiency and selectivity by regulating the electronic structures of the active center through the bimetallic synergistic effect [14–17]. Consequently, significant research has been conducted to develop dual-atom catalysts with high EcNRR activity and selectivity [18–20]. The FeMo dual-atom catalyst has been demonstrated both theoretically and experimentally as an efficient catalyst for EcNRR. Experimentally, Li et al. [21] synthesized FeMoNXC catalyst by using the N-doped graphene as substrate, the obtained catalyst achieving an NH3 yield rate of 14.95 µg h-1 mg-1 at −0.4 V, along with a faradaic efficiency of 41.7 % at −0.2 V. Liu et al. [22] synthesized a FeMo/NC catalyst comprising Fe-Mo sub-nanoclusters and single atoms on N-doped porous carbon, which achieved an NH3 yield rate of 26.5 ± 0.8 μg h-1 mgcat -1 at −0.3 V. Similarly, Chang et al. [23] reported a binary Mo/Fe catalyst (MoFe-NC) supported on N-doped carbon, which exhibits a maximum N2 reduction faradaic efficiency of 39.9 % and a NH3 yield rate of 28.5 µg h-1 mgcat -1. Theoretically, the density functional theory (DFT) method has been used for understanding the structures and reaction activity of EcNRR on the dual-atom catalysts. In general, two types of FeMo dual-atom catalysts on a nitrogen-doped graphene substrate were proposed in which the Fe and Mo coordinated to 3-N and 4-N atoms to form FeMo(3 N)@NG and FeMo(4 N)@NG, respectively (Fig. 1 a). The FeMo(4 N)@NG is more stable than FeMo(3 N)@NG [24,25]. However, the reaction mechanism and NRR thermodynamics are still controversial. For the EcNRR on FeMo(4 N)@NG, Li et al. [21] reported the EcNRR proceeds an alternating pathway through side-on mode with N2 adsorbed at Fe and Mo atoms simultaneously, regarding the release of the second NH3 as the rate-determining step, the calculated maximal ∆G is 0.906 eV. However, Gao et al. [24] and Han et al. [25] reported different results in which the N2 adsorbs at the Mo atom through an end-on mode and reduced to NH3 through a distal route, regarded the first hydrogenation step as the potential determining step (PDS). The calculated ∆G max are 0.63 and 0.55 eV, which are close to each other. In their calculations, the N2 adsorbed onto Mo atom through end-on modes is more stable than adsorbed onto both Fe and Mo atoms. Thus, it is crucial to reasonably evaluate the stability of N2 adsorption in order to clarify the reaction mechanism. In the other FeMo dual-atom catalyst FeMo(3 N)@NG, He et al. [26] and Zhu et al. [27] proposed an enzymatic mechanism involving a side-on configuration, where N2 adsorbs simultaneously at both Fe and Mo atoms. However, He et al. [26] regarded the last hydrogenation step as PDS, with ∆G of 0.36 eV, while Zhu et al. [27] predicted the first hydrogenation step as PDS, the ∆G is 0.43 eV. In another theoretical work presented by Zheng et al. [28]. Their calculated results revealed that the N2 adsorb at Mo atom in an end-on mode is more stable than adsorb at FeMo through side-on mode. Based on the N2 adsorption stability, they predicted the thermodynamically favorable pathway is alternating, where the fourth hydrogenation step is PDS, and the ∆G is 0.98 eV. Therefore, the differences in these works reflect the importance of a comprehensive consideration of the adsorption of N2 at metal bi-sites in order to understand the reaction mechanisms, which also inspired us to further explore the reaction thermodynamics and kinetics of EcNRR on FeMo dual-atom catalysts. Considering the variability associated with the computational models and parameters used in different works, in Table S1, we summarized the computational methods employed and key values for NRR on the two types of FeMo dual-atom catalysts to facilitate a better comparison. Furthermore, non-metallic heteroatom modifications play a key role in modulating the catalytic activity of active center [29]. Sulfur, as an important non-metallic element, is known to regulate the electronic state of the metal active center of the catalyst and is widely used in heterogeneous catalytic reactions such as NRR [30–32] and ORR [33]. Hence, it is also our intention to conduct further theoretical research into the potential for modifying the EcNRR efficiency of FeMo dual-atom catalysts through S modifications. This study has two main goals. First, six distinct N2 adsorption configurations were calculated by using the DFT method for the two types of FeMo dual-atom catalysts with N-doped graphene (FeMo@NG). The most favorable thermodynamic pathways and activation barriers were calculated and compared with previous reports, and the electronic structures were calculated to analyze the intrinsic origin of N₂ activation on the two types of FeMo@NG catalysts. Second, the sulfur atom was introduced to replace the nitrogen atom in the two types of FeMo@NG, and nine different FeMo bimetallic anchored nitrogen, sulfur-modified graphene (FeMo@NSG) catalysts were formed. The optimal S substitution way for improving EcNRR was identified through thermodynamic and kinetic calculations. The effect of S modification on the electronic structure of the active center of FeMo@NSG was examined. This research will furnish theoretical counsel for subsequent elemental modification of dual-atom catalysts in the EcNRR performance. 2 Computational details A 5 × 5 single-layer graphene structure was first constructed, with the optimized lattice parameter of 2.467 Å. The formation of a nitrogen-doped graphene substrate involved the removal of four C atoms and the subsequent replacement of six C atoms surrounding the C vacancy with N atoms. Then Fe and Mo atoms were anchored to the vacancies to form the FeMo(4 N)@NG and FeMo(3 N)@NG catalysts (Fig. 1a). Given that the FeMo(4 N)@NG and FeMo(3 N)@NG catalysts exhibit three and six types of N atoms with different coordinate environments, respectively. Subsequently, nine configurations of FeMo@NSG were considered, and the scheme is presented in Fig. 1a. The formation energies of S atom substitution of N atom were given (1) E f = E d o p e d + E N − ( E p e r f + E S ) where E N and E S are single-atom energies of N and S atoms, E doped and E perf are the electronic energies of S-modified and unmodified FeMo dual-atom catalysts. All spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations were employed in the Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [34]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [35] with the exchange-correlation functional of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [36] within the projected augmented wave (PAW) [37] method was applied. The electronic wave functions were expanded on a plane-wave basis setting up to an energy cutoff of 450 eV. The converged criteria were set to 10–5 eV and 0.02 eV/Å for electronic energies and force on atoms, respectively. A 3 × 3 × 1 mesh of Monkhorst-Pack k points was used to simplify Brillouin zone integration for structural optimization, while the k point 9 × 9 × 1 for electronic structure calculations was used. The vacuum layer thickness was set to 16 Å along the Z-direction to avoid periodic image interaction. The van der Waals (vdW) interaction between adsorbates and catalysts was described by empirical dispersion correction in Grimme’s scheme (DFT+D3) [38]. Bader charge analysis was employed to investigate the charge transfer between the catalyst and adsorbates [39]. The Gibbs free energy of each elementary reaction was calculated based on the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model [40]: (2) Δ G = Δ E + Δ Z P E − T Δ S + Δ G U + Δ G pH where ∆E is the reaction electronic energy difference between the product and the reactant of the EcNRR elementary reaction step, which is obtained directly from DFT calculations. Vibrational zero-point energy correction (∆ZPE) and vibrational entropy (∆S) were obtained by vibrational frequency calculations, where the substrates were frozen, and all intermediates were verified with no image frequency existing to ensure structural stability. T is the Kelvin temperature, which is set to 298.15 K under standard conditions. ∆GU is the energy contribution of electrode potential (U), ∆GpH is the free energy correction of pH, which was set to pH=0 in this work, corresponding to the case of the standard hydrogen electrode. The overpotential was calculated by the formula: [41] (3) η = − Δ G max e − ( − 0.16 ) where the ∆Gmax is the maximal free energy change (in unit of eV) in the potential determining step (PDS) in the whole EcNRR reaction, and −0.16 V is the equilibrium potential of nitrogen reduced to ammonia [42]. The activation energy calculations were performed based on the Marcus theory as previously reported [43,44]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 EcNRR thermodynamics on FeMo@NG catalysts For N₂ adsorbed on FeMo@NG catalysts, there are six N₂ adsorption configurations, as illustrated in Fig. 1b According to the end-on and side-on adsorption modes, four reaction pathways were considered, as shown in Fig. 1c. The optimized structures of FeMo(4 N)@NG and FeMo(3 N)@NG are depicted in Fig. 2a-2b and Figure S1. The Fe-N and Mo-N bonds in the symmetrical FeMo(4 N)@NG catalyst have two types of bond lengths. For example, the calculated Fe-N bond lengths are 1.922 and 1.883 Å, while the Mo-N bond lengths are 2.045 and 1.870 Å, respectively. Both N atoms binding to the Fe and Mo atoms have shorter Fe-N and Mo-N bond lengths compared with those of side Fe(Mo)-N bonds. The calculated distance between the Fe and Mo atoms is 2.261 Å, which is consistent with the reported value of 2.26 Å [25]. In the FeMo(3 N)@NG structure, the six bond lengths of Mo-N and Fe-N are different due to the different coordination environments of the six N atoms. The Fe-N bond lengths vary from 1.903 to 2.038 Å, while the Mo-N bond lengths change from 2.027 to 2.243 Å. The Fe-Mo bond length is 2.040 Å, which is shorter than that in FeMo(4 N)@NG. From the calculated results of structural parameters, it can be seen that the bonding properties of metal atoms and N atoms at the two types of catalytic centers are different, and also the distances between Fe and Mo atoms [25,28]. These factors may affect the N2 adsorption and EcNRR catalytic activity. The calculated structures and corresponding adsorption Gibbs free energies of N₂ on the two catalysts through six N₂ adsorption configurations are depicted in Fig. S2. For FeMo(4 N)@NG and FeMo(3 N)@NG catalysts, the adsorption of N₂ is difficult to achieve in a dual-end mode. The adsorption of N₂ at Mo atoms through the end-on mode is the most favorable. The corresponding ∆G values are −0.50 and −0.42 eV, which is consistent to the value of −0.58 [25] and −0.42 eV [28], respectively. This indicates that the N₂ adsorption is slightly more stable at FeMo(4 N)@NG than that at FeMo(3 N)@NG. On the basis of the most favorable end-on adsorption mode, the thermodynamic pathways and transition states of the EcNRR on FeMo(4 N)@NG and FeMo(3 N)@NG were calculated, the calculated results were presented in Fig. 2c-2d and Fig. S3. The distal pathway emerges as the thermodynamically preferred route for reducing N₂ to NH₃ on FeMo(4 N)@NG (Fig. 2c), while the alternating pathway is shown in Fig. S3a. The optimized intermediate configurations are presented in Fig. S4. The first hydrogenation step is identified as the thermodynamical PDS with a ∆G of 0.50 eV, corresponding to an overpotential of −0.34 V. The calculated activation energy (E a) of the first hydrogenation step is 0.87 eV. In the second hydrogenation step, the ∆G of the formed intermediate, *NNH₂, is calculated to be −0.12 eV, with an E a of 0.44 eV. The release of the first NH3 is highly exergonic, with a ∆G of −0.70 eV, leaving behind the *N intermediate. The subsequent hydrogenation free energy changes were −0.60, −0.24, and 0.23 eV, corresponding to intermediates of *NH, *NH₂, and *NH₃, respectively. The calculated activation energies were 0.54, 0.39, and 0.68 eV, respectively. The PDS energy barrier of 0.50 eV for EcNRR on FeMo(4 N)@NG is consistent with the previously reported thermodynamic PDS energies of 0.55 [25] and 0.63 eV [24], which adopted the Mo atom as the adsorption site, and also the first hydrogenation steps is PDS within the distal route. Thus, for the EcNRR on FeMo(4 N)@NG, the calculated results revealed that the first hydrogenation step is the PDS with an overpotential of −0.34 V, and the calculated activation energy is 0.87 eV, which is the rate-determining step (RDS). The FeMo(3 N)@NG catalyst facilitates the end-on adsorption mode of N₂ onto the Mo atom with a ∆G of −0.42 eV. The calculated distal and alternating pathways are depicted in Fig. 2d and Fig. S3b. The EcNRR also facilitates a distal pathway, exhibiting the first hydrogenation step as the PDS with ∆G of 0.53 eV, which corresponds to an overpotential of −0.37 V. The calculated E a of the PDS is 0.97 eV. The optimized intermediates are shown in Fig. S5. The Gibbs free energy changes of subsequent hydrogenation reactions are −0.01, −1.23, 0.34, −0.16, and 0.14 eV, corresponding to the formation of intermediates *NNH2, *N, *NH, *NH2, and *NH3, respectively. The calculated E a for each elementary step is shown in Fig. 2d. Over the whole distal route, the RDS also corresponds to the first hydrogenation step with an E a of 0.97 eV, which is slightly higher than the RDS of FeMo(4 N)@NG, indicating the EcNRR on FeMo(4 N)@NG is more thermodynamically and kinetically favorable. Notably, Zheng et al. [28] previously reported an alternating pathway on FeMo(3 N)@NG, they proposed that N2 preferred to adsorb at the Mo atom with an end-on configuration and the fourth hydrogenation step is PDS with a ∆G of 0.99 eV. Nevertheless, our calculations indicate that the distal route is more energetically favorable than the alternating pathway (Fig. S3b). 3.2 Electronic structure analysis on FeMo@NG To gain further insight into the origin of the catalytic activity of N2 on FeMo(4 N)@NG and FeMo(3 N)@NG, we performed charge density difference, Bader charge, and projected density of states (PDOS) calculations. Table 1 presents the Bader charge and bond lengths before and after the N2 adsorption on both catalysts. The Bader charges indicate that the valence states of Mo and Fe atoms on FeMo(4 N)@NG are higher than those on FeMo(3 N)@NG. This discrepancy can be attributed to the differing coordination numbers of N atoms in the two types of FeMo@NG catalysts. The charge density difference analysis reveals substantial charge transfer between the substrate and the N2 after the N2 adsorption at FeMo@NG in the end-on form (Fig. S6). Bader charge calculations showed that the N2 received 0.30 and 0.29 e- from FeMo(4 N)@NG and FeMo(3 N)@NG, resulting in the bond lengths of the adsorbed N2 being stretched to 1.142 and 1.140 Å, respectively. The bond lengths of adsorbed N2 were significantly longer than that in free N2 (1.115 Å), reflecting that the N2 molecule is effectively activated on both catalysts. It is noteworthy that the charge density difference also indicates that Fe atoms are involved in the electron exchange in the N2 adsorption process on both FeMo@NG catalysts. As evidenced by the Bader charge calculations presented in Table 1, the Mo atoms that serve as adsorption sites lose more charge. In both FeMo@NG systems, there are 0.19 e- transferred from the Mo atoms to the N2 and the surrounding atoms. Conversely, the Fe atoms gain 0.05 and 0.06 e-, respectively. In contrast to SACs, the introduction of Fe atoms in the dual-atom catalysts shows that the Fe atom induced charge aggregation, and further regulated the charge transfer of the Mo atom and the adsorbed intermediates. As evidenced from the charge density calculations in Fig. S7, in the FeMo(4 N)@NG, the Mo atom further loses electrons and becomes more positively charged compared to Mo(4 N)@NG, while the Fe atom gains electrons and becomes less positively charged. The charge redistribution after the formation of dual-site reflects the synergistic effect between Fe and Mo atoms and further facilitates the EcNRR. The PDOS of N2 adsorbed on FeMo(4 N)@NG and FeMo(3 N)@NG are shown in Fig. 3a-3b Before the adsorption of N2, the metal atoms exhibit a significant distribution of electronic states around the Fermi level, suggesting that FeMo(4 N)@NG and FeMo(3 N)@NG possess favorable electronic structures and conductivity properties. The calculated results indicate that the d-band center of Mo is higher than that of Fe on FeMo@NG catalysts. The d-band centers of Mo and Fe on FeMo(4 N)@NG are found to be −0.58 and −0.77 eV, while they are −0.60 and −1.14 eV on FeMo(3 N)@NG, respectively. The higher d-band center of the Mo atom implies its stronger adsorption ability with N2 [45], in agreement with the previously calculated adsorption free energy values (Fig. S2). The binding interaction was further analyzed according to the molecular orbital theory. As Mo is employed as the adsorption site on both FeMo@NG catalysts, following the adsorption of N₂, there are resonance hybridization peaks between the p-orbitals of N₂ and the d-orbitals of Mo atoms. Additionally, the Fe atoms also participate in electron exchange with N2. There are also several orbital hybridization peaks of N2 p-orbitals with d-orbitals of Fe atoms, which demonstrate the synergistic effect of dual-atom catalysts. Compared with free N2 (Fig. S8), the 2π and 3σ energy levels of the adsorbed N2 are shifted downward, which reflects the bonding interaction between the N2 and the Mo atom. The peak of the PDOS for the N2 molecule 2π* orbital splits into multiple peaks, with some of these split peaks shifted below the Fermi level. This phenomenon can be attributed to the π-backdonation effect, whereby electrons in the occupied d-orbitals of Mo atoms are transferred to the 2π* orbitals of N2. Therefore, the donation-backdonation mechanism formed after the bonding of N2 with the substrate effectively promotes the activation of nitrogen molecules. 3.3 The effect of sulfur modification on the EcNRR of FeMo@NSG In order to study the effect of the S-modification on EcNRR performance, one sulfur atom was further introduced to replace a N atom in FeMo(4 N)@NG and FeMo(3 N)@NG catalysts in nine different ways, as shown in Fig. 1a. The calculated formation energies of S substitution of N atoms on the FeMo(4 N)@NSG and FeMo(3 N)@NSG catalysts are presented in Table S2. The initial focus is on the effect of S-atom modification on N2 adsorption of FeMo(4 N)@NSG, as well as on EcNRR. Fig. 4a-4c present three schematic structures of FeMo(4 N)@NSG and the adsorption free energies through six N₂ adsorption configurations, where the optimized structures are depicted in Fig. S9. On FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S1, N2 exhibits the greatest stability at the Mo atom in an end-on mode, with a ∆G of −0.76 eV. On FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2, N2 tends to adsorb at Mo atom in either end-on or side-on modes, with ∆G of −0.36 and −0.33 eV, respectively. On FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S3, N2 also preferred to adsorb at the Mo atom in either end-on or side-on modes, with ∆G of −0.52 and −0.57 eV, respectively. Compared to the FeMo(4 N)@NG with a ∆G of −0.50 eV for N2 adsorption through end-on mode at the Mo atom, it is obvious that FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S1 and FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S3 can further promote the adsorption of N2 on FeMo(4 N)@NSG. In light of the aforementioned findings regarding the most favorable N2 adsorption patterns on the three types of FeMo(4 N)@NSG catalysts, a detailed analysis was conducted to ascertain the thermodynamic pathways associated with the EcNRR reaction. The dominant thermodynamic reaction pathway after N₂ adsorption on the Mo atom (end-on) on FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S1 is distal, as illustrated in Fig. S10. The first hydrogenation step, with a ∆G of 0.58 eV, is the PDS. In comparison to the FeMo(4 N)@NG without S modification (Fig. 2c), the NRR performance was not promoted. The reduction of N2 to NH3 in end-on and side-on forms was investigated on the FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2, and the thermodynamic pathways are presented in Fig. 5 and Fig. S11, respectively. A detailed analysis will conducted later. In the case of FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S3, the examination of the four thermodynamic reaction pathways reveals that N2 is most likely to be reduced via the distal pathway (Fig. S12). Furthermore, the initial hydrogenation step is identified as the thermodynamic PDS, with a ∆G of 0.48 eV. In comparison to FeMo(4 N)@NG, the PDS energy barrier slightly decreases a lower value than 0.50 eV. Fig. S11 also illustrates the free energy profile for the N2 reduction by the enzymatic and hybrid pathways, which exhibit a ∆G max of 0.76 eV (*N*N→*N*NH). The EcNRR on FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2 can be significantly promoted by the introduction of the S atom. The calculated structure and geometric parameters of FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2 are shown in Fig. 5a. The introduction of S atoms breaks the symmetry of the local structure. After the sulfur atom modification, the coordination environment of each N atom changes, and the bond lengths of Fe-N and Mo-N are stretched or compressed. The alteration of geometry by the modification of the S atom can further affect the electronic structures of the metal center and EcNRR catalytic performance [31,32]. For the end-on adsorption mode of N2 at the Mo atom, both distal and alternating reaction paths were calculated (Fig. 5b and Fig. S11a). The results demonstrate that the N2 molecule is more likely to be reduced in a distal manner, and the optimized intermediates are depicted in Fig. S20. By inspection ∆G and E a values of each elementary step along the entire distal route, the PDS is the first hydrogenation step with a ∆G of 0.31 eV, corresponding to an overpotential of −0.15 V. However, the RDS is the last hydrogenation step, which is different from the PDS. The calculated E a in the RDS is 0.77 eV, which is lower than 0.87 eV in FeMo(N4)@NG. Conversely, for N2 adsorbed as side-on mode on FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2, the free energy profile via the enzymatic and hybrid pathways is illustrated in Fig. S11b. The initial step of the hydrogenation process is PDS, with a ∆G of 0.70 eV, which is thermodynamically unfavorable compared to the distal route. Our focus now shifts to the six classes of catalysts formed by different S substitutions of FeMo(3 N)@NG. On six FeMo(N3)@NSG catalysts, each one has the six modes of adsorption free energies under consideration illustrated in Fig. S13. Similarly to the preceding discussion, the most stable adsorption configuration and detailed thermodynamic pathways for these reactions were systematically evaluated. Fig. S14-S19 illustrates the EcNRR thermodynamic pathways on the formed FeMo(3 N)@NSG. An analysis of all thermodynamic reaction pathways reveals that only FeMo(3 N)@NSG-S1 and FeMo(3 N)@NSG-S2 have promoted the EcNRR performance. In both cases, the first hydrogenation step is the PDS, the ∆G max are 0.50 and 0.47 eV with both Mo as the adsorption site through the distal route. Thus, our calculated overpotentials are 0.34 and 0.31 V, the EcNRR catalytic performance was only slightly promoted due to the S modification. In conclusion, the introduction of S atoms has been demonstrated to affect not only the adsorption mode and strength of N₂, but also the thermodynamics and kinetics of the EcNRR. Among these catalysts, the enhancement of the EcNRR performance of the formed FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2 has been found to be the most significant, with its overpotential further reduced from −0.34 V to −0.15 V, and activation energy barrier decreased from 0.87 to 0.77 eV. 3.4 Exploring the origin of catalytic activity of the FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2 The above-calculated results suggested that the FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2 catalyst exhibited the most pronounced NRR catalytic activity among FeMo@NSG catalysts. Next, this section will undertake a more detailed investigation of the electronic structures of FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2 and the role played by the S atom. The Bader charge changes of the Fe, Mo, S atoms, and N2 molecules were calculated before and after the adsorption of N2 on FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2, and the results are presented in Table 2 . Before the N2 adsorption, Fe, Mo, and S atoms are positively charged with +0.72, +1.21, and +0.13 respectively, with the Mo atom losing the most electrons. The valence states of Fe and Mo after S-modification are decreased. After the N2 adsorption, Fe and Mo continue to lose electrons to become more positively charged with +0.82 and +1.43. The N2 molecule takes 0.32 e- from the substrate, which causes the bond length to be stretched to 1.142 Å. It is worthy of note that for FeMo(4 N)@NG, the N2 adsorption induced the Fe atom to gain 0.05 e-, while the Mo atom lost 0.19 e-. After the modification of the S atom, the adsorption of N2 results in further electron losses of 0.10 and 0.22 e- for Fe and Mo atoms, respectively. This indicates that the modification of the S atom is capable of not only modulating the electronic structure of the active site but also altering the electronic effect of neighboring metal sites. After the N2 adsorption, the S atom gains considerable electrons of 0.35 e-, thereby influencing a transition from a positive to a negative characterization of its charged states, which demonstrates the charge aggregation effect of the S atom. The charge density difference distribution further supports this phenomenon, as illustrated in Fig. 6 a. In comparison to FeMo(4 N)@NG, the N atom of the substrate before S-substitution gains 0.16 e-, which reflects the stronger charge aggregation ability of the S atom. We further performed crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) calculations to investigate the effect of S-atom doping on the catalyst, as well as on the N2 adsorption and activation. As shown in Fig. S21, before N2 adsorption, the bond strength of Mo-S after S-modification is slightly lower than Mo-N. The introduction of S-atom could decrease the bond strength of Fe-Mo, the calculated ICOHP increases from −2.43 to −2.05, which is also reflected by the bond lengths change from 2.261 to 2.369 Å. After the N2 adsorption, the introduction of S-atom would decrease the Mo-N bond strength between the adsorbed N2 molecule and the Mo atom, the calculated ICOHP change from −4.36 to −4.31, which is consistent with the N2 adsorption energy changes. Besides, the introduction of S-atom would promote the activation of N2, the ICOHP increases from −22.09 to −21.95, which is consistent with the Bader charge and bond length values in Table 2. The role of S-atom modification in modulating the electronic structure of bimetals was further analyzed through PDOS calculations. As illustrated in Fig. 6b and 6c, the d-band centers of both Fe and Mo atoms are shifted downward following S-atom modification, indicating an increase in the number of electrons in the occupied d-orbitals. This is in accordance with the results of our Bader charge calculations, as presented in Tables 1 and 2. Nevertheless, the d-band center of Mo (−0.85 eV) is still higher than that of Fe (−0.99 eV), which indicates that the adsorption ability of Mo atom with N₂ remains superior to that of Fe atom. This finding aligns with the preceding calculation in Fig. 4, which suggests that N₂ exhibits a propensity to adsorb onto the Mo atom. However, in comparison to the d-band center of Mo in FeMo(4 N)@NG (−0.58 eV), the decrease in the d-band center following S modification can result in a weakening of the adsorption of N2, which could lead to the decrease of the adsorption energy from −0.49 to −0.36 eV. Fig. S22 illustrates the orbital interactions before and after N2 adsorption on FeMo(4 N)@NG-S2. Additionally, the PDOS demonstrates that the π-backdonation mechanism effectively activates N2. In order to gain deep insight into the role of S atoms in the NRR process, we conducted further calculations of the Bader charges of Fe and Mo atoms of adsorbed intermediates throughout the entire EcNRR process (Fig. 6d). As mentioned above, the introduction of S can result in charge aggregation and modification of metal electronic structures. Throughout the EcNRR process, it was observed that the valence states of Mo atoms were lower than those of Mo atoms without S atom modification when adsorbing intermediates, except for the Mo atom after adsorbing the intermediate NH2. Since the low oxidation state of transition metal generally possesses higher reactivity [46], thus we calculated the valence states of Mo atoms when the Mo atoms serve as the stable N2 adsorption sites. The relationship between the valence states of Mo atoms and limiting potential is shown in Fig. 7 and Table S3, a curve similar volcano map can be obtained. This phenomenon illustrates the moderate oxidation state of Mo after S-modification can promote the EcNRR. Besides, the Fe atoms in FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2 exhibited lower oxidation states and more gradual valence state alterations in comparison to FeMo(4 N)@NG, reflecting the fact that Fe atoms present a role of charge storage and transfer, rather than acting as a site for the provision of electrons in the NRR. Combined with the valence state changes after N2 adsorption before and after S-modification, the role of the Fe atom that modulates the active center and promotes the N2 activation can be further proved. However, the alteration in the charge carried by the intermediates before and after the S modification is ignorable. Concerning the role of Mo atoms as adsorption sites, given that the stretched bond lengths of N2 before and after S-atom modification are comparable, the observed enhancement of the catalytic activity of FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2 NRR can be attributed to the reduction in the thermodynamic energy barrier associated with the initial step of the hydrogenation process. The S atom, which results in an aggregated charge, causes Mo atoms to consistently exhibit a lower oxidation state throughout the reaction process. This also leads to a greater number of electrons being occupied and lower d-band centers, which ultimately contributes to a moderate bonding strength between the metal center and intermediates. The combined effect of S atom modification and FeMo bimetallic resulted in enhanced catalytic activity for nitrogen reduction. 3.5 NRR selectivity and catalyst stability We further calculated the hydrogen adsorption free energies on FeMo(3 N)@NG, FeMo(4 N)@NG and FeMo(4 N)@NG-S2 to evaluate the NRR selectivity. In the DAC, where Fe and Mo atoms act as active centers, the hydrogen can adsorb onto the Fe or Mo atom of the catalyst. The calculated ∆G of hydrogen adsorption on these three catalysts is depicted in Fig. S23. In the FeMo(3 N)@NG, the HER occurs more favorably at the Fe site due to the calculated ∆G is 0 eV. In the FeMo(4 N)@NG, the calculated ∆G of hydrogen adsorption onto Fe and Mo sites are 0.40 and −0.31 eV, which indicates that the HER takes place at the Mo atom. However, the calculated ∆G of hydrogen adsorption onto Fe and Mo atoms are much more negative in the FeMo(4 N)@NG-S2. This is due to the adsorption of hydrogen induces a localized distortion of the catalyst from an initially planar structure to a structure with protruding S atoms, as shown in Fig. S21a. The structural distortion leads to the electronic energy change, thus resulting in a more negative ∆G of hydrogen adsorption. We further calculated the limiting potential differences between NRR and HER to evaluate the NRR selectivity, and the results are shown in Fig. S21b. The results reveal that the FeMo(3 N)@NG possesses low NRR selectivity, while the S-modified FeMo(4 N)@NG-S2 exhibits higher NRR selectivity. We calculated the binding energies of Fe and Mo atoms anchored onto the substrate of (4 N)NG, 3N(NG) and (4 N)@NG-S2 to evaluate the stability of these three catalysts, the results are listed in Table S4. From the calculated binding energies, we can infer that the FeMo(4 N)@NG is much more stable than FeMo(3 N)@NG and FeMo(4 N)@NG-S3, which is consistent with the previous report that the FeMo(4 N)@NG is more stable than FeMo(3 N)@NG [24,25], the average binding energy is −9.01 eV. However, the FeMo(3 N)@NG shows comparable stability to FeMo(4 N)@NG-S2, the calculated average binding energies are −6.03 eV. We further verified the thermodynamic stability of FeMo by ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD), the result is shown in Fig. S24. After 10 ps structural relaxation at 300 K, there was no obvious distortion of the structure and the dissolution of metal atoms, indicating that the structure had good thermodynamic stability. 4 Conclusion In this work, we initially conducted DFT calculations to assess the thermodynamics and kinetics of the EcNRR on FeMo(4 N)@NG and FeMo(3 N)@NG. The results demonstrate that the N₂ molecules preferentially adsorb at Mo atoms in an end-on configuration, offering more stability. The distal pathway emerged as the thermodynamically favorable pathway, with the first hydrogenation step as the PDS. The calculated overpotentials of the reaction are 0.34 and 0.37 V, and the kinetic energy barriers are 0.87 and 0.97 eV for FeMo(4 N)@NG and FeMo(3 N)@NG, respectively. The electronic structure calculations show that both types of catalysts can promote the activation of N2 efficiently, thus realizing the efficient reduction of N2. Furthermore, the DOS calculations show that the d-band centers of Mo are higher than those of Fe on both FeMo(4 N)@NG and FeMo(3 N)@NG, validating Mo as the adsorption site. Based on the above research, we further doped S onto the two types of FeMo@NG catalysts and determined the most favorable adsorption mode by considering nine different modifications. Following this, detailed thermodynamic calculations were performed for the EcNRR on FeMo@NSG. The calculation results reveal that the FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2 catalyst formed by S atom modification, exhibits the most pronounced enhancement in NRR catalytic activity. The N2 is adsorbed on Mo sites in an end-on form, and the distal pathway reduces to ammonia. The first step of hydrogenation is the PDS, and the reaction overpotential is −0.15 V, while the last hydrogenation step is RDS with an activation energy barrier of 0.72 eV. Calculations of the electronic structure demonstrate that the S atom exhibits a stronger charge aggregation effect. This effect modulates the electronic state of the metal center and also changes the nature of the neighboring Fe atom. The modification of S atoms has been observed to decrease the d-band center and weaken the adsorption ability of metal atoms. The active Mo center possesses moderate oxidation states after S-modification in the EcNRR and thus enhances the catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: Dual-atom catalysts have received increasing attention in electrochemical ammonia synthesis in recent years due to their ability to break the scaling relationship limit. Experimental and theoretical evidences have demonstrated that FeMo bimetallic co-doped nitrogen-modified graphene (FeMo@NG) can serve as an efficient nitrogen reduction catalyst. However, the thermodynamic reaction mechanism remains a topic of debate. In this study, we employed density functional theory (DFT) calculations to examine the nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) on FeMo dual-atom catalysts and the effect of sulfur modification on the catalytic performance. Two types of FeMo dual-atom catalysts, including 4-N and 3-N coordinated structures, exhibited low NRR thermodynamic and kinetic barriers. The calculated overpotentials are -0.34 and -0.37 V (vs. SHE), while the activation energy barriers are only 0.87 and 0.97 eV, respectively. Nine different sulfur substitution ways were considered to form the FeMo-anchored nitrogen, sulfur-modified graphene (FeMo@NSG) catalysts. It was found that the formed FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2, in which the sulfur atom replaces the nitrogen atom simultaneously bonded to Fe and Mo atoms, can enhance the NRR performance dramatically. The FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2 catalyst exhibits a lower overpotential of -0.15 V (vs SHE) and faster kinetics with an energy barrier of 0.77 eV than other catalysts. The electronic structure analysis reveals that the modification of the S atom decreases the d-band center and weakens the adsorption ability of the active metal center, thereby resulting in a moderate oxidation state and higher reactivity. Therefore, this catalyst FeMo(4 N)@NSG-S2 will possibly possess a significant advancement in the field of electrochemical ammonia synthesis. This work not only predicts a promising dual-atom electrocatalyst candidate for NRR but also contributes to the advancement of efficient NRR catalysts by regulating atomic coordination environments.
